Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain is a bizarre game to try and talk about because it sits at a particularly awkward crossroads. It is arguably one of the best games of the 2010s, taking the exploding genre of open world games and cracking it open by offering players extreme freedom in the way they tackle tightly-designed missions. This push and pull between developer intention and player choice could have easily been a tension point, but ultimately works because a player‚Äôs ability to complete a level is entirely based on their own resourcefulness and creativity. Within a player‚Äôs toolkit are nearly infinite ways to complete their mission objective, with the player only being limited by the tools they have on-hand or intrinsic objectives such as high mission rankings or a desired low kill-count. These are all great attributes and are a huge part of why MGSV is hailed today as a masterpiece. 

The issue with that framing is that MGSV doesn‚Äôt exist in a vacuum. Kojima‚Äôs Metal Gear is perhaps the single most-revered game series in existence, with each one being hailed as a masterpiece of gameplay, storytelling, and technical achievement. As impressive as MGSV is, it is directly competing with its predecessors, and the comparison is not particularly flattering. As fun, slick, and rewarding as its action is, the game‚Äôs storytelling and pacing ultimately disrupt that experience in a way the game never really manages to outrun. 

The game is ultimately paced to have two distinct arcs, with one being the effective ‚Äúmain‚Äù conflict and the second arc laying the groundwork for how MGSV connects to the rest of the Metal Gear franchise. Of these two arcs, the first is by far the most-interesting, containing 32 episodes with the majority of them containing important story content. While most of these missions are excellent, some really fall short of expectations, leading to a few duds in an otherwise excellent list. And, honestly, if you wanted to check out after Mission 31, I don‚Äôt think I would blame you. Most of the story of MGSV is, perhaps intentionally, disjointed, hazy, and dreamlike, intentionally setting up conflicts that connect to the rest of the series. These are largely presented in the form of Mother Base cutscenes, forming a clear and present disconnect between the gameplay and story that the game never manages to shake. 

Perhaps the game‚Äôs biggest sin is that it‚Äôs simply meandering and filled with padding. Out of the 51 missions (prologue included) present in the main game, 24, by my count, are either challenge missions with specific restrictions in-play, or are completely unrelated to the game‚Äôs story and are largely disposable. Most of these missions exist after the conclusion of the first arc; another reason the second arc manages to fall so flat. Of the 19 missions present in the second arc, 15 are of this type, leading to an abysmal 4 main story missions past Mission 31. And, of these 4, one is a partner mission and another is a repeat of a previous mission, just with extra story context added in. This is a huge part of why the back half of the game feels so empty and underwhelming: because nothing you do makes a difference. Much of this is also because the game‚Äôs actual conclusion, Mission 51, was never properly finished. There‚Äôs a lot of documentation out there online about it, and I would encourage you to check it out if you‚Äôre left wanting more after Mission 48. Based on unfinished cutscenes and concept art, it probably would have been the game‚Äôs best mission, and I doubt it would have left fans disappointed. 

But even among many of these complaints, I actually have quite a few positive things to say about the game‚Äôs story and presentation. I might be alone in thinking this, but I REALLY enjoy MGSV‚Äôs codec tapes. The game has a TON of extra context and information contained in tapes players unlock as they progress through missions. Most of these are either designed to further elaborate on cryptic elements of the main game or provide historical context for the larger story, but some of them are also there just as fun side-stories that play out on Mother Base. Of these, my favorite has to be ‚ÄúThe Hamburgers of Kazuhira Miller,‚Äù which unironically got me to really appreciate fast food burgers. If you can sit through that and not crave a Bic Mac, you are stronger than I am. That said, none of these tapes are necessary for story purposes and you can just as easily ignore them. Perhaps the most-interesting and important tapes are ‚ÄúThe Truth‚Äù tapes found right at the end of the game. If you‚Äôre interested in what happened to the main cast of Snake Eater following MGS Ground Zeroes, they‚Äôre worth a listen. 

I also really enjoy how much side content the game has. The game has 157 Side-Ops, most of which are simple side-missions that can be done in the open world. Most of these showcase MGSV at their best, with specific small goals in play that players can attack in any way they want without having to worry about score or rank. There are plenty of duds in this selection, but the vast majority are pretty engaging, with missions like ‚ÄúEliminate the Armored Vehicle Unit‚Äù and ‚ÄúExtract the Highly Skilled Soldier‚Äù taking up much of the list. As interesting as side content is in the main world, some of the most-interesting content available takes place on your iDroid. The game has a particularly engaging system of progression, where you work to grow Mother Base and even online content where you can compete to infiltrate each-others bases. I‚Äôm not personally that interested in MGSV‚Äôs online side, but it can be a huge draw for extending playtime. I know a few people that have put more hours into the game‚Äôs online content than the main game, so it‚Äôs definitely worth a look.

I want to maintain that MGSV is still one of the best games of its time and absolutely worth a playthrough. But I also want to point out the game‚Äôs failures, as I don‚Äôt think it is as easy to recommend as many of its series predecessors. If the lack of a solid conclusion to its story and overall emphasis on freedom sound like potential deal-breakers for you, I‚Äôm not sure you should bother. Still, even with all its shortcomings, I think MGSV earns its title as a Metal Gear Solid game. It‚Äôs not a perfect entry, but it‚Äôs a brilliant action game that manages to brilliantly balance an intricately crafted world with deep and rewarding gameplay.

Metal Gear Solid V is a game that somehow manages to be both a deeply serious war drama and one of the most absurd sandboxes ever designed, where every stupid thing you do becomes a legend. And that contrast is exactly why it works.

I already knew the franchise, and I actually tried MGSV for the first time about eight years ago. And I dropped it, probably too early. Back then, all I really absorbed were the memes and the confusing revelation that more than one Snake exists.

Only after finishing Death Stranding recently did I feel the urge to return to MGSV, and I‚Äôm glad I did.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

What makes MGSV exceptional is its sandbox design - a stealth-sandbox hybrid unlike anything I‚Äôd played before. Missions can be approached from countless angles. The game just hands you a toolbox and says: "Figure it out". It reminded me of Death Stranding in that sense: the joy of pure autonomy, where every victory feels earned, and every failure becomes your own story.

One of MGSV‚Äôs most brilliant achievements is how its anti-war message is expressed not just in dialogue, but directly through gameplay. Enemies adapt to your actions: kill too many, and they start wearing heavy armor and helmets. It‚Äôs a subtle, realistic reinforcement of the game‚Äôs unspoken rule: "don‚Äôt kill unless you must."

Yet the game never forbids combat. In fact, it makes fighting so enjoyable that sometimes it‚Äôs hard not to indulge. Especially when it comes to XOF, mercenary executioners with absolutely no humanity. I took enormous satisfaction in hunting them down. I replayed the Skullface mission many times even after I‚Äôd stripped the entire base of every resource, probably committing a full-scale mercenary genocide in the process. One-man army delivering justice. And then there‚Äôs that infamous ten-minute jeep ride. I didn‚Äôt skip it the first three (?) times.

[b]Story and Symbolism[/b]

The story ended up impressing me the most. I absorbed it with genuine delight. I jumped through every bizarre hoop Kojima set up to unlock secret missions and true endings, and I did it willingly.

Even in its hidden content, Kojima‚Äôs symbolism shines through. For example, having to defeat Quiet seven times to bring her back. MGSV‚Äôs narrative layers reward obsession, and I was happy to indulge.

But what struck me the hardest weren‚Äôt the twists or secrets - it was the way the game occasionally drops all irony and reminds you that war isn‚Äôt spectacle, but pain you can‚Äôt dodge. There are moments when all the absurd freedom of MGSV suddenly collapses into one blunt truth: sometimes you have to do what no one else will. There‚Äôs no stealth workaround, no trick, no mercy. Just a decision so heavy it shakes even a legend.

I could talk about the story for hours - but in short, it delivered some of the most memorable emotional beats.

[b]Are there any downsides?[/b]

The game isn‚Äôt flawless. Some difficulty spikes - for example, the sudden encounters with the Skulls - felt unfair. The game barely prepares you for them, forcing you to improvise under pressure. Still, these moments rarely overshadow the experience as a whole.

[b]The Vibe[/b]

MGSV has a unique atmosphere - a blend of absurd humor, heavy seriousness, and the exhausted PTSD-soaked aura of a war veteran clinging to whatever humanity he has left.

The game is serious, but it also knows that serious faces are just masks. And sometimes it mocks that seriousness - intentionally and beautifully.

It‚Äôs a rare combination: emotional weight and mechanical freedom.
A world where every mistake, every triumph, every random act of stupidity becomes part of Big Boss‚Äôs legend - or whoever you choose to be.

An Absolute Stealth Masterpiece with Lore That Bites Back

Hours Played: 30
Rating: 10/10 (Highly Recommended)

If you're looking for the ultimate evolution of the stealth-action genre, look no further than Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain (MGSV TPP). I‚Äôve sunk countless hours into this game, and it remains one of the most rewarding and purely fun experiences on Steam.

Gameplay: Freedom, Funk, and Fulton

At its core, MGSV is an awesome stealth action 3rd person shooter, but the level of player freedom it offers is unmatched. The open-world environment is a sandbox where every mission is a puzzle with infinite solutions. Do you go in during the day with sniper support? Or infiltrate at night using only CQC and silenced weapons? The choice is yours, and the moment-to-moment gameplay‚Äîcrawling through the dirt, tagging enemies, and pulling off the perfect extraction‚Äîis incredibly polished and satisfying. Plus, who doesn't love attaching a balloon to a sleepy goat and sending it up to space? The base-building and recruitment systems are addictive and give a real sense of growth and consequence to your actions.

Story & Lore: Crazy, Wild, and Essential

For series veterans and newcomers alike, the story here is a triumph. The lore is crazy and wild in the best ways. Hideo Kojima takes classic Metal Gear themes of war, identity, and loyalty and cranks them up to 11. The narrative is often complex, sometimes confusing, and always deeply rewarding. It features some of the most memorable characters and jaw-dropping twists you‚Äôll find in gaming. Don't worry if you haven't played the previous games‚Äîyou'll still enjoy the ride, but if you do some reading, the sheer scale of the Metal Gear universe is intoxicating.

The Verdict

If you are looking for a game with rock-solid third-person shooting, unparalleled tactical stealth, and a truly unforgettable story, then this is the game to get. It's a technical marvel, a mechanical masterpiece, and a truly essential piece of gaming history.

[b]Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain[/b] just never clicked for me.  The pacing felt all over the place: some cutscenes dragged on forever, others made it seem like the story was finally gaining momentum, only for the game to swerve into a tangent for several missions.  Any mission involving the supernatural group known as "The Skulls" completely took me out of the experience.  They are frustrating rather than tense or exciting, and they feel out of sync with the grounded stealth gameplay the series is known for.

The deeper I got, the more repetitive it became.  Most of Act 2 is made up of modified rehashes of Act 1 missions, and the side ops all blur together as copy-and-paste scenarios at different outposts.  Even the main missions practically demand multiple playthroughs: your initial run, then replaying to clear side objectives that only unlock after finishing the mission [i](see note below)[/i], and then replaying yet again for an S-rank that usually requires zero kills.  Multiply that by the repeated missions in Act 2 and suddenly you're doing the same tasks up to six times.  And don't even get me started on the opening hospital sequence.  It goes on forever, constantly swapping between cutscene and gameplay so you never know when the skip button will work.  Yes, you may end up sitting through it multiple times too.

I know the game's development was notoriously messy, with Konami and Kojima clashing behind the scenes and parts of the narrative reportedly left unfinished.  That context explains a lot of the unevenness, but it doesn't make it any easier to play through.  There are flashes of brilliance here, and I really appreciate the graphics and core stealth mechanics, but the overall experience just didn't land for me.

[i]Side objective note: Technically, you can complete them on your first run, but some require extracting a target in a completely different outpost off the intended path.  When you go there, there are even voice lines telling you you're going the wrong way.  There is no way to know about these objectives without looking them up.[/i]

An [okay] game. The worst game in the MGS series, not worth playing unless you are really, really interested into MGS. The story itself provides a lot of context that bridges the MGS timeline. However, it takes so much time just to get those pieces feels awful, and storytelling is not like the other MGS games.

The reason behind all the flaws in the game is "Live-Service" and mixing online with Single-player elements. The MB Coins, aka "Time-savers" are especially criminal and a huge red flag for any game. The presence of time-savers means game elements are designed to entice the purchase of the coins, making game elements less interesting, rewarding less to take up more of your time. Personally lost all interest in "collecting" and side activities and did not bother with them after I realized that I could just swipe my credit card instead of playing the game.

[h3] Story [/h3]

Completely disconnected storytelling, drop in from a helicopter, find the target, and extract via helicopter. Over and over, with just a few exceptions. The areas felt similar, and overall, each mission felt more and more repetitive.
The story itself felt fragmented and incoherent. Some of the main missions offered little to no story, felt like a chore.

Disconnected storytelling, fragmented story, 'time spent' to 'story delivered' ratio is awful. Nothing like the previous games.

[h3] Replayable Missions [/h3]

This was especially weird and contributed to the issues with the story and storytelling. Nothing wrong with them being replayable, except each mission had the same loop of drop-in-> infiltrate ->exfiltrate, which caused the lead to the previously mentioned story issues.

On top of that, each mission had optional objectives that, often, especially early, were impossible to complete within a single run. Additionally, those optional objectives were hidden until you complete the mission. FURTHERMORE, each mission had scoring with fat rewards, which required effectively to focus on the main objective and doing it fast (apparently, cutscenes do not stop the "mission timer", leading to a lower score). 

Thus, if you want to complete all objectives, you have to play the second time since you don't even know them until you complete the mission. The later in the game you replay it, the easier it is to complete them. So, maybe you just focus on the main objectives so you complete that S rank, but without the prior knowledge, it's harder to get the S.

This scoring and unknown secondary objectives are awful if you just want to play the game and enjoy the story. If you play on your own pace and explore/discover some of the objectives, you are likely to neither complete all nor get the S. Meaning you'd have to replay the mission twice to get S and objectives. The S giving a fhat reward means you should simply ignore and go for the main objective, but this is just awful.

[h3] Base management [/h3]

Base elements are nice, until you realize, hey, why would I spend these 5 minutes collecting 100 "materials" if I can swipe my card and get 10000? Hey, why do I bother clearing outposts that take so much time and risk so much to extract a few A or A+ soldiers if I can swipe a card and get 45 of them?

Without swiping your card, you are likely to fall behind on the development and which will simply make you spend more time to complete the mission instead of making it more challenging.

The only other downside for the research and progression was that it leaned heavily into offensive rather than stealth, offering little to make stealth easier or something different than using a tranq-pistol.

Giving this game a thumbs down really hurts.  Metal Gear Solid on PS1 is my favorite game of all time, and I have played through it more than a twenty times.  I also grew up playing Metal Gear on the NES, and despite its flaws, still hold it in the highest regard.  I think Hideo Kojima is an absolute genius, but like many people of his caliber, needs someone to bring him back to earth from time to time.  From what I can see, no one was there for this game.  After MGS1, I was never really able to connect with this franchise.  Despite this, I played through all of them until I hit a wall with MGSV.

The stories got more weird and the characters failed to live up to my expectations as time went on.  MGS2 pulled the rug out from under Snake fans, and while MGSIII brought the series back to the bad ass hero, I think the die on Metal Gear was already cast. All this said, there is a lot to love here.  What this game gets right is absolute perfection.  There is no denying that Hideo Kojima is a master of storytelling.  Unfortunately, where MGSV lags is an anchor that weighs down the overall experience.

The Good:
	1.  Kiefer Sutherland is a great replacement for David Hayter, who was for me the definitive voice of Snake.  I even appreciated that they went a different route to distance Big Boss from the MGS1 Snake.  He delivers a masterful performance and really shines in every scene.
	2.  The storytelling and direction are top notch, though not without hiccups.  When he is down to earth, Kojima knows how to create an amazing narrative.  While it does go out into space from time to time, the good parts outweigh the bad.  If you can cut through the crazy, there are great themes and truly mind altering experiences.  
	3.  The stealth and general gameplay mechanics are solid (pun intended).  I had some trouble with previous MGS games, but this one clicks, after some work.
